messages.author: timsteele
messages.text: I like the idea of having a comment here (and in frontend_data_...), but perhaps explaining the rationale rather than restating the code is better?

messages.author: lipalani1
messages.text:
On 2012/02/23 04:15:23, timsteele wrote:
> I like the idea of having a comment here (and in frontend_data_...), but perhaps
> explaining the rationale rather than restating the code is better?

Done.

messages.author: timsteele
messages.text: Sanity check - are we sending up multiple unrecoverable errors to bpad for the same failure, but at different layers of the code?

messages.author: lipalani1
messages.text:
It is possible. We could send upto 2 crash reports. But from the call stack it will be clearly visible the failure was due to a syncable operation and then we can look for that call stack. If it is not a syncable operation then the call stack should say what caused it.

The way to fix this would be to remember we have uploaded and that is pretty tricky because of all the threads.
On 2012/02/23 04:15:23, timsteele wrote:
> Sanity check - are we sending up multiple unrecoverable errors to bpad for the
> same failure, but at different layers of the code?

messages.author: timsteele
messages.text: Does this mean we'll upload a stack every time a basic network hiccup occurs during config?  I'm a bit concerned that it isn't really a unique enough situation to warrant sending (might be better served by UMA?).  I guess we can try it out..

messages.author: lipalani1
messages.text:
No I have already fixed that. In non desktop like platforms we will simply wait. In windows desktop if there is a network error during setup the unrecoverable error will be thrown from PSS. The error from here is a legitimate "I asked you to download x but I havent gotten x".
On 2012/02/23 04:15:23, timsteele wrote:
> Does this mean we'll upload a stack every time a basic network hiccup occurs
> during config?  I'm a bit concerned that it isn't really a unique enough
> situation to warrant sending (might be better served by UMA?).  I guess we can
> try it out..
